title: I broke my phone TWICE! - Is Karma finally catching up?!
description: Well... its happened. After two years, my personal phone has broken TWICE. It does not work anymore. My curved screen Note 10 Plus has kicked the bucket. But can we fix it? Today we are going to try and repair my personal phone with a delicately tuned medial procedure perfected by Dr. Frankenstein. Taking two broken phones... and merging them into one working device. How long have you had your current phone? let me know down in the comments.  Get my razor knife here!    Anker is named as the Official Charging Partner of JerryRigEverything:    *Follow me for updates!* Instagram:  Facebook:  Twitter:   LARGE tool kit:  Travel Tool Kit:  Mega Tool Kit:  Plastic Pry tools:  Metal phone opening tool:  Replacement phone parts:   The camera I used to film this video:  The Lens I used for this video:  Wide angle lens:  And this Metabones adapter:  This is the drone I use:   TO SEND ME STUFF: See my P.O. Box on my 'About page':   JerryRigEverything assumes no liability for property damage or injury incurred as a result of any of the information contained in this video.  JerryRigEverything recommends safe practices when working with power tools, automotive lifts, lifting tools, jack stands, electrical equipment, blunt instruments, chemicals, lubricants, expensive electronics, or any other tools or equipment seen or implied in this video.  Due to factors beyond the control of JerryRigEverything, no information contained in this video shall create any express or implied warranty or guarantee of any particular result.  Any injury, damage or loss that may result from improper use of these tools, equipment, or the information contained in this video is the sole responsibility of the user and not JerryRigEverything. Only attempt your own repairs if you can accept personal responsibility for the results, whether they are good or bad.
transcript: So I never break phones on accident, but last week I broke my personal phone twice doing very normal things. This crack over here wasn't a big deal, I was just lifting a chair out of the back of a car, which is something I do often. As I lift the chair out of the vehicle, the chair rests on my pocket which has my phone in it. And after two years of doing that repetitively, it broke my screen. I was just going to leave it since it's cosmetic and everything still works. But a couple days later I broke my phone again. My phone slid out of my pocket while sitting down in my office chair, and the edge of my screen hit the wheel of my chair and then fell onto carpet. But when the edge of the screen came in contact with the wheel, it shattered the side of the phone and broke more than just the glass...which rendered my phone pretty much useless. Without a screen there's not a whole lot you can do. So now we have two options. I could go get another phone. It has been two years, so I could kind of buy another phone relatively guilt-free. Usually, I like to use my phone for a bit longer. But two years is nothing to frown upon and it's what most of you suggested over on Twitter. But I got to thinking...iFixit has said if every single American were to keep their phone for an extra year, it would take the equivalent of 600,000 cars off the road. Which is a pretty big deal. And my mom always says, Use it up, wear it out, make it do, or do without. And she's a pretty big deal. But unfortunately though, my phone cannot make do anymore since the screen is one of the more important parts of a cellphone. So it's time to get a little creative and see if we can Frankenstein this thing back together with one of my durability tested phones that you've seen here previously about 2 years ago. Sometimes using a donor phone for parts is cheaper than buying brand new replacement parts. This is a Note 10 Plus 5G so who knows, maybe I'll have 5G once I'm done with the repair. There's only one way to find out. Let's get started. [Intro] Frankensteining things together is actually kind of fun, it's the act of taking two broken phones and splicing them into one to make a working device. Just like a pick a part automotive junk yard where you can go in and grab the parts you need off of a wrecked vehicle so you can keep your own vehicle running longer. The unicorn sneeze colored Note 10 Plus is an international phone so it won't work with my carrier here in the USA. It doesn't have the right antennas for me to just plop my SIM card into. But I'm hoping at least the screen and the frame part are interchangeable, even if it has been scratched up and durability tested two years ago. I'll take the Teardown Skin off my non-psychedelic black phone and it looks like I've been a lot harder on my phone than I thought. My back glass is also shattered...probably because I've been double bagging it with a skin and a case which most likely puts a lot of extra pressure on that rear glass. Definitely not doing that anymore. Plus I've been keeping my gym key card tucked into the case, which adds even more stress. All things that I will avoid doing from now on. If I can bring my phone back to life, I'm going to be a whole lot nicer to it. Normally when I tear down a phone there's no emotional attachment, but this guy has been in my pocket for two years now, so I'm really hoping that it'll live again. With some heat from my heat gun and slices from my razor knife, we can soften and remove the adhesive holding the cracked back glass in place. And then we can do the same thing to the melted pile of skittles over here. It's much easier and quicker since it was already taken apart once a few years ago. So far things are looking positive. The screw holes appear to be in the same positions on both phones even though they are international and domestic variance. Not the kind of variance that concern the TVA of course, but the screw holes being in the same locations mean that the motherboard transplant might be feasible. Each Note 10 Plus has 9 screws holding down the back plastics and wireless charger over the motherboard. I almost forgot to show you the boot screen, which as you can see is locked to an SK telecom in South Korea. Not super useful if I want to use it here in the USA. I'll pop off all the little ribbon connectors just like little Lego's. And then do the same thing for my own phone, with it's 9 screws and little ribbons. I can remove the SIM card trays and then pop out the stacked motherboard with their attached camera modules. I kind of forgot that I sliced up and removed the copper vapor chamber during the teardown. I'm realizing that I'm not very nice to phones in general. I'll steel the vapor chamber from my old phone and slap it into the kaleidoscope. And luckily, even with the different chips and antennas, my US variant motherboard fits inside of the international frame. This might just work after all. As far as 5G goes though, as you can see, the slots for the 5G millimeter wave antennas are empty on my old phone, and they are also missing on the South Korean variant. So neither one of them has a super fast 5G and I won't end up with 5G after this is all over. Surprisingly though, the international phone with my own motherboard installed does turn on and shows the background of my old phone with all my apps and information. It's good to see them again. The problem though, which is kind of a big deal, is that I have no cell service, even after installing my SIM card. So we're going to have to try something else. The lack of cell signal could be one of two things: the phone could be looking for the charging port board, or more likely, it's looking for the back plastics which have the silver antennas lines baked on. To be on the safe side, I'll just move them all over. I'll plop my charging port board into the crayon box colored phone, along with my own loudspeaker, which as you can see has the silver antenna lines built onto the black plastics. I'll also make sure that I'm using the top plastics that previously covered the motherboard from my old phone since as we can see, the antenna lines on these parts are also different between the variants, and I need mine to work here in the USA. With all of the insides pretty much swapped over, we start delving into the metaphysical realm of the ship of Theseus. At one point did my phone stop being my phone, as the individual parts are replaced? The screen is different, the battery is different, and the frame is different. Even the color is different. But the insides, where it matters, my phone is indeed still the same, and surprisingly, still functional. You can even make phone calls. [Cambry] Hello. -How are you doing? -Can you hear me? -Yes I can. Can you hear me? -Yes. Did you have dinner? -Yeah, I did. I just fixed my phone. I'm just making sure it worked. -Oh. Alright. Well I'm on my way home. -Perfect. See you in a minute. Love ya. -Love you. Bye. -Not too shabby. There are still plenty of useful parts remaining in my previous phone, like the earpiece, battery, vibrator, and even the frame. It's always a good idea to recycle your phone. There's still plenty of value to even very broken phones. Even though my new phone now has scratches at level 6, with deeper grooves at a level 7, a burn mark as well as scratches over the ultrasonic fingerprint reader, and no water resistance, I still very much prefer it to my totally broken display. And hopefully, this transplant will let me continue to use my phone for another year or two. Use it up, wear it out, make it do, or do without. I'm curious to know how long you've been using your current phone. Let me know down in the comments. Come hang out with me on Instagram and Twitter. And thanks a ton for watching. I'll see you around.
